This week on @PublicHealthPod, @SDesmon and @DrJoshS are teaming up to talk to experts about multiple aspects of #COVID19 vaccine mandates.

Listen to today‚Äôs episode with @BermanInstitute's Nancy Kass to learn more about ethical considerations.

As of August 23, 2021, Pfizer-BioNTech's #COVID19 vaccine has full @US_FDA approval.

FDA previously granted emergency use authorization (EUA) for individuals ages 16+ in December 2020, and later expanded that EUA to include ages 12-15.

"In 2020, during the pandemic‚Äôs first year, suicides among white residents [of Illinois] decreased compared with previous years, while they increased among Black residents, according to state data. But this is not a local problem." https://t.co/cFU3jdecvy

"I have no safety concerns about a booster shot. But this remains a pandemic of the unvaccinated. That's what is fueling this surge," said @IVACtweets's William Moss.

"Getting more people vaccinated should be our No. 1, 2, and 3 priorities." https://t.co/abvBmRPxud

For pandemic-weary Americans who got their #COVID19 shot at the first opportunity, vaccine hesitancy can be difficult to understand.

But for social and behavioral scientist @Rupali_Limaye, the reasons are clear, and it boils down to one word: Trust. https://t.co/BXM0ywVc90

Pregnant and recently pregnant people are at an increased risk for severe #COVID19 when compared with non-pregnant people. But getting an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine during pregnancy reduces these risks‚Äîand may also provide some protection for breastfed babies.  https://t.co/gC4pU61wqD
